description: From Middle French prebende, from Medieval Latin prebenda, from Late Latin praebenda, from Latin praebendus, verbal adjective of praebere. Doublet of provender.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A stipend paid to a canon of a cathedral.
(obsolete) The property or other source of this endowment.
examples: He is said to have added prebends to Southwell; it is more probable that he gave estates to the church which were afterwards made into separate prebends.
a lease of the prebend of Withington

verbs.description: prebend (third-person singular simple present prebends, present participle prebending, simple past and past participle prebent)

examples: For large and/or dense bones compression plate fixation achieves absolute stability but the fragments have to be in contact remote to the plate by prebending the plate.
